title: Virgin Money extends deadline on 37-month 0pc credit card
text:
UBGXF 0.00 
Product review: Virgin's 37-Month 0% balance transfer credit card will be available until 2 November, but is it the best? 
Virgin Money has extended the availability of its 37-Month Balance Transfer Credit Card* . 
The card was originally only available for a 20-day period up until 30 September, but will now be available until 2 November. 
Is it as good as it looks? 
While the card offers the longest 0pc pay back period on the market, there are a few things to consider. 
The transfer has to be made within 60 days of signing up. 
The card also applies 0pc on interest when you transfer money from the card into your bank account, which is fairly rare. However, a 4pc fee is applied. Some borrowers do this to pay off other debts elsewhere as part of a risky balancing act. 
There’s also a 2.79pc fee on balance transfers. 
In terms of these fees, customers could get a better deal on a 36-month credit card, if they were confident they could pay off the balance a month sooner. Barclaycard's Platinum card offers 36 months at 0% with a 2.39pc balance transfer fee, and for the same interest free time period, Halifax charges a 2.45pc fee. You can cut fees further by getting a balance transfer card with a shorter 0pc term. 
• PPI deadline looms: should I claim £2,750 now? • 'MBNA cancelled my credit cards' 
Not everyone will be eligible for the card with the company weeding out those with poor credit histories. If unsuccessful, Virgin Money won’t offer applicants a shorter option. 
Once the fee-free period is over, customers will be charged 18.9pc on balance transfers and 20.9pc on money transfers, a little above the average. 
Andrew Hagger of Moneycomms said: "Consumers shouldn't be blinkered into opting for the deal purely based on the longest duration. They need to factor in the one-off balance transfer fee. With Virgin Money's 2.79pc fee this would cost £139.50 on a £5,000 switch." 
Barclaycard, with one month less of interest, charges 1.75pc for balance transfers so it would cost just £87.50. Halifax offers 20 months at 0pc with no balance transfer fee. 
Mr Hagger added: "Borrowers should be aware that if they exceed their credit limit or are late with a monthly payment the promotional 0pc deal is terminated on the spot and their balance is then charged at the go to rate which in the case of Virgin Money is 18.9pc APR representative."
